commands.name: Sit
commands.description: The foundation command. Your dog learns to plant their bottom on the ground and wait for the next cue.

steps.instruction: Hold a treat close to your dog's nose so they can smell it.
steps.tip: Use a high-value treat they really love

steps.instruction: Slowly move your hand up and back over their head. Their nose will follow the treat, causing their bottom to lower.
steps.tip: Move slowly - if they jump, you're going too fast

steps.instruction: The moment their bottom touches the ground, click (or say 'Yes!') and give the treat immediately.
steps.tip: Timing is crucial - mark the exact moment they sit

steps.instruction: Add the word 'Sit' just before luring. Say it once, clearly.
steps.tip: Only add the verbal cue after they understand the motion

steps.instruction: Practice 5-10 reps per session, 2-3 sessions daily. Gradually fade the lure by reducing hand movement.

tips: Keep sessions short - 5 minutes max
End on a success, even if you have to make it easier
Practice in different locations once reliable at home
commonMistakes: Repeating the command multiple times - say it once
Pushing their bottom down (this creates resistance)
Training when the dog is tired or overstimulated

commands.name: Stay
commands.description: Your dog learns to remain in position until released, even with distractions.

steps.instruction: Ask your dog to sit. Show your palm (stop signal) and say 'Stay.'
steps.tip: Keep your body calm and still

steps.instruction: Wait 1 second, then click/treat while they're still sitting. Release with 'Okay!'
Gradually increase duration: 2 seconds, 5 seconds, 10 seconds, 30 seconds.
steps.tip: If they break, you went too fast - go back to an easier duration

steps.instruction: Add distance: take one step back, return, and reward. Gradually increase steps.
steps.tip: Build duration before adding distance

steps.instruction: Add distractions: drop a toy nearby, have someone walk past, practice outdoors.
steps.tip: Add one distraction at a time, reduce duration when adding new challenges

tips: Always return to your dog to reward - don't call them to you
Use a clear release word consistently
The 3 D's: Duration, Distance, Distraction - add one at a time
commonMistakes: Increasing difficulty too quickly
Forgetting to use a release word
Calling the dog out of the stay (teaches them to break)

commands.name: Down
commands.description: Your dog learns to lie down with elbows and belly on the ground.

steps.instruction: Start with your dog in a sit. Hold a treat at their nose.
steps.tip: Make sure they're calm before starting

steps.instruction: Slowly lower the treat straight down to the floor between their front paws.
steps.tip: Go slow - their nose should follow like a magnet

steps.instruction: Once the treat is on the floor, slowly drag it away from them. They should slide into a down.
steps.tip: If they stand up, you moved too fast

steps.instruction: The moment elbows touch the ground, click and treat.
steps.tip: Mark the exact moment of success

steps.instruction: Add the verbal cue 'Down' just before the hand motion once they understand it.

tips: Some dogs find this easier on a soft surface
Try luring from a stand if sit-to-down isn't working
Capture natural downs - reward when they lie down on their own
commonMistakes: Moving the lure too quickly
Pushing the dog down physically
Getting frustrated - stay patient and positive

commands.name: Come (Recall)
commands.description: The most important safety command. Your dog learns to come to you immediately when called.

steps.instruction: Start indoors with minimal distractions. Say your dog's name + 'Come!' in an excited voice.
steps.tip: Sound happy and exciting - never angry

steps.instruction: When they look at you, run backwards encouraging them to chase you.
steps.tip: Make yourself the most interesting thing in the room

steps.instruction: When they reach you, throw a party! Multiple treats, praise, petting.
steps.tip: Coming to you should be the best thing ever

steps.instruction: Practice in gradually more distracting environments: backyard, quiet park, busy park.
steps.tip: Use a long line (15-30 feet) for safety outdoors

steps.instruction: Never call your dog for something unpleasant (bath, nail trim, leaving the park).
steps.tip: Go get them instead for non-fun activities

tips: Never chase your dog - always move away from them
Never punish a dog for coming to you, even if it took a while
Practice randomly throughout the day, not just training sessions
commonMistakes: Using 'Come' for things the dog doesn't like
Repeating the command over and over
Calling when you can't follow through (dog is too distracted)

commands.name: Heel
commands.description: Your dog walks beside you in a precise position, focused and attentive.

steps.instruction: Decide which side (traditionally left). Hold treats in that hand at your hip.
steps.tip: Consistency is key - always use the same side

steps.instruction: Lure your dog to your side. Say 'Heel' and take one step forward.
steps.tip: Start with just one step

steps.instruction: If they stay at your side, click and treat at hip level. If they forge ahead or lag, stop.
steps.tip: Treat at your hip so they learn the position

steps.instruction: Gradually increase steps: 2, 3, 5, 10, 20 before treating.
steps.tip: Vary the number of steps to keep them guessing

steps.instruction: Add turns, changes in pace, and distractions as they improve.
steps.tip: Make it a game - be unpredictable

tips: Heel is for focused attention - use 'Walk Nice' for casual walks
Keep sessions short - heel position is mentally tiring
Use high-value treats and lots of engagement
commonMistakes: Expecting too much duration too soon
Treating too low (teaches head-down position)
Not being interesting enough - compete with the environment

commands.name: Leave It
commands.description: Your dog learns to turn away from something tempting when asked.

steps.instruction: Hold a treat in your closed fist. Let your dog sniff and paw at it. Wait.
steps.tip: Don't say anything yet - let them figure it out

steps.instruction: The moment they back off or look away, click and give a DIFFERENT treat from your other hand.
steps.tip: Always reward from the opposite hand

steps.instruction: Add the cue: say 'Leave it' before presenting your closed fist.
steps.tip: Say it once, calmly

steps.instruction: Progress to treats on the floor covered by your hand, then uncovered.
steps.tip: Be ready to cover it quickly if they go for it

steps.instruction: Practice with various items: toys, food on walks, squirrels (from a distance).
steps.tip: Always reward with something equally good or better

tips: Never let them get the forbidden item - it becomes a game
Use increasingly tempting items as they improve
Practice in real-life situations once reliable
commonMistakes: Letting them eventually get the 'leave it' item
Not making the reward worthwhile
Using it for items you'll eventually give them

commands.name: Drop It
commands.description: Your dog releases whatever is in their mouth immediately.

steps.instruction: Start with a toy your dog likes but isn't obsessed with. Let them take it.
steps.tip: Choose a lower-value toy to start

steps.instruction: Show them a high-value treat near their nose. The moment they release the toy, say 'Drop it' and give the treat.
steps.tip: Say the cue AS they drop, not before

steps.instruction: Immediately give the toy back after they eat the treat.
steps.tip: This teaches that dropping doesn't mean losing

steps.instruction: Practice with increasingly valuable items: better toys, chews, etc.
steps.tip: Always trade for something equally good or better

steps.instruction: Start saying 'Drop it' before showing the treat. Reward when they comply.
steps.tip: Fade the treat lure gradually

tips: Always trade up - never just take things away
Practice with random household items (safe ones)
Never chase or grab - this makes guarding worse
commonMistakes: Taking the item and not giving something in return
Chasing the dog to get the item
Only practicing with low-value items

commands.name: Wait
commands.description: A temporary pause - different from Stay. Used at doors, before meals, getting out of the car.

steps.instruction: At a doorway, ask for a sit. Say 'Wait' and reach for the door handle.
steps.tip: Don't open the door yet

steps.instruction: If they stay sitting, crack the door slightly. If they move, close it and reset.
steps.tip: The door closing is the consequence - stay calm

steps.instruction: Gradually open the door wider. Release with 'Okay!' when they can wait with door fully open.
steps.tip: Be patient - this can take many reps

steps.instruction: Practice at meal times: 'Wait' before putting the bowl down.
steps.tip: Start with just a second, build up

steps.instruction: Use 'Wait' before: exiting cars, crossing streets, entering/exiting crates.
steps.tip: Consistency in daily life makes it reliable

tips: Wait is temporary - Stay is longer duration
The reward is often the thing they're waiting for (going through door, eating)
Use this for safety at every threshold
commonMistakes: Letting them rush through if they break
Not using a release cue
Being inconsistent - sometimes letting them rush

commands.name: Watch Me
commands.description: Your dog learns to make and hold eye contact with you on cue.

steps.instruction: Hold a treat near your dog's nose, then move it to the bridge of your nose between your eyes.
steps.tip: They'll naturally look at the treat, which means looking at your eyes

steps.instruction: The moment they make eye contact, even briefly, click and treat.
steps.tip: Start with a split second of contact

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Watch me' or 'Look' before the hand motion.
steps.tip: Say it once in a friendly tone

steps.instruction: Gradually increase duration: 1 second, 2 seconds, 5 seconds of eye contact.
steps.tip: If they look away, just try again - no punishment

steps.instruction: Practice in distracting environments. Use this to redirect attention from triggers.
steps.tip: This is a powerful tool for reactive dogs

tips: Make eye contact pleasant - smile and use a happy voice
Great for photo ops too!
Use before giving other commands to get focus
commonMistakes: Staring intensely (can be threatening to some dogs)
Moving too fast to longer durations
Only practicing at home

commands.name: Place
commands.description: Your dog goes to a designated spot (bed, mat, crate) and stays there until released.

steps.instruction: Choose a distinct 'place' - a dog bed, mat, or raised platform. Stand near it with treats.
steps.tip: A raised surface (even a low platform) helps dogs understand boundaries

steps.instruction: Lure your dog onto the place with a treat. The moment all four paws are on, click and treat.
steps.tip: Click exactly when the last paw lands

steps.instruction: Add 'Down' once they're on the place. Reward for lying down on it.
steps.tip: Lying down helps them settle

steps.instruction: Build duration: start with 5 seconds, work up to minutes. Release with 'Okay!'
steps.tip: Toss a treat away when releasing to get them moving

steps.instruction: Increase distance from the place. Practice sending them from across the room.
steps.tip: Point at the place when giving the command

tips: Make the place super comfortable
Give long-lasting chews on the place to build positive associations
Use during meals, guests visiting, or when you need focus time
commonMistakes: Using place as punishment ('Go to your place!')
Not having a clear boundary for the dog to understand
Expecting long durations before building up

commands.name: No Jump
commands.description: Your dog greets people politely with four paws on the floor.

steps.instruction: When your dog jumps, immediately turn your back and cross your arms. Say nothing.
steps.tip: All attention stops - no talking, no eye contact, no pushing

steps.instruction: The moment all four paws hit the floor, turn back and calmly praise/treat.
steps.tip: Keep your energy calm so they stay calm

steps.instruction: Ask for a sit before greetings. Only pet/greet when sitting.
steps.tip: Sitting is incompatible with jumping

steps.instruction: Recruit helpers to practice. Everyone must follow the same rules.
steps.tip: Inconsistency from any person sets training back

steps.instruction: For excited dogs, give them something to do: fetch a toy, go to place, etc.
steps.tip: Redirect the energy instead of just suppressing it

tips: Prevent practice of jumping - management is key
Exercise before guests arrive to take the edge off
Everyone in the house must be consistent
commonMistakes: Pushing the dog off (this is attention!)
Yelling 'No!' or 'Off!' (also attention)
Allowing jumping sometimes ('but he's so happy!')

commands.name: Quiet
commands.description: Your dog learns to stop barking on cue.

steps.instruction: First, teach 'Speak' (barking on command). This gives you control over the behavior.
steps.tip: It seems counterintuitive, but teaching 'speak' helps teach 'quiet'

steps.instruction: Ask for 'Speak.' After 1-2 barks, hold a treat at their nose. They'll stop barking to sniff.
steps.tip: The treat interrupts the barking

steps.instruction: The moment they stop barking, say 'Quiet' and give the treat.
steps.tip: Mark the quiet, not the stopping

steps.instruction: Gradually increase the duration of quiet before treating: 1 second, 3 seconds, 5 seconds.
steps.tip: Build slowly

steps.instruction: Practice with real triggers (doorbell, strangers) starting at low intensity.
steps.tip: Start with quiet recordings of triggers

tips: Address the root cause of barking (boredom, fear, alerting)
Interrupt the bark cycle early - don't wait until they're frenzied
Reward calm behavior throughout the day, not just training
commonMistakes: Yelling 'Quiet!' (sounds like you're barking with them)
Waiting until barking is intense to intervene
Not addressing underlying causes

commands.name: Off
commands.description: Your dog removes themselves from furniture, people, or counters when asked.

steps.instruction: When your dog is on furniture, show a treat and lure them to the floor.
steps.tip: Toss the treat on the floor to get them moving

steps.instruction: Say 'Off' as they're getting down. Click and treat when all paws hit the floor.
steps.tip: Pair the word with the action

steps.instruction: With counter surfing, set up training scenarios. Put boring item on counter, reward for not investigating.
steps.tip: Management is key - don't leave tempting items out

steps.instruction: For persistent counter surfers, use an 'incompatible behavior' - teach 'Go to Place' during kitchen time.
steps.tip: Reward heavily for being on their bed in the kitchen

steps.instruction: Be consistent - if something is off-limits, it's always off-limits.
steps.tip: Mixed signals confuse dogs

tips: Different from 'Down' which means lie down
Management prevents practice of unwanted behavior
Provide appropriate alternatives (dog bed, dog-friendly furniture)
commonMistakes: Using 'Down' when you mean 'Off'
Allowing access sometimes
Leaving tempting items on counters and expecting willpower

commands.name: Go To Bed
commands.description: Your dog goes to their designated sleeping spot and settles there.

steps.instruction: Stand near your dog's bed. Toss a treat onto it. When they go to get it, click.
steps.tip: Make the bed rewarding from the start

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Go to bed' just before tossing the treat.
steps.tip: Say it once, clearly

steps.instruction: Gradually stand further from the bed when giving the command.
steps.tip: Work up to sending them from across the room

steps.instruction: Once on the bed, ask for 'Down' and reward. Then add duration with stay.
steps.tip: Layer commands for a complete behavior chain

steps.instruction: Give special chews or treats ONLY on the bed. It becomes their happy place.
steps.tip: Positive associations build reliability

tips: Make the bed the most comfortable spot in the house
Location matters - put it somewhere they can see you
Use at bedtime and during household activities
commonMistakes: Using the bed as timeout (creates negative association)
Uncomfortable or too-small bed
Not releasing them - they need to know they can leave eventually

commands.name: Settle
commands.description: Your dog learns to calm down and relax, even in stimulating environments.

steps.instruction: Capture calmness: whenever your dog lies down and relaxes on their own, quietly say 'Settle' and drop a treat between their paws.
steps.tip: Don't make a big deal of it - stay calm yourself

steps.instruction: Practice 'Relaxation Protocol' exercises (Karen Overall's protocol is excellent).
steps.tip: Search 'Karen Overall Relaxation Protocol' for the full program

steps.instruction: Use a specific mat for settle training. This becomes a 'chill zone.'
steps.tip: The mat becomes a cue for relaxation

steps.instruction: Practice in gradually more exciting environments: TV on, visitors, outdoor caf√©.
steps.tip: Build up very slowly - don't rush environmental difficulty

steps.instruction: Use calming signals: long, slow blinks, relaxed body, quiet voice.
steps.tip: Your energy affects your dog's energy

tips: Settle is a state of mind, not just a position
Exercise first if your dog is too hyper to focus
This takes time - be patient
commonMistakes: Expecting calm behavior from an under-exercised dog
Adding excitement with high-pitched praise
Rushing to difficult environments

commands.name: Greet Politely
commands.description: Your dog meets new people calmly without jumping, barking, or overwhelming them.

steps.instruction: Practice sit-stays while someone approaches. Start with family members, low excitement.
steps.tip: Build the foundation at home first

steps.instruction: The approacher stops if the dog breaks the sit. Only continues when sitting again.
steps.tip: The reward (greeting) depends on calm behavior

steps.instruction: When sitting for the entire approach, the person can pet briefly, then step back.
steps.tip: Keep greetings short to prevent excitement buildup

steps.instruction: Have treats ready. After calm greeting, toss treat away from the person to create space.
steps.tip: This resets the scenario for another practice rep

steps.instruction: Practice with new people in controlled scenarios before real-world situations.
steps.tip: Set up practice sessions with patient friends

tips: Exercise before social situations
Use a front-clip harness for better control if needed
Some dogs do better with structured activities than free greetings
commonMistakes: Allowing the person to pet an excited dog ('they don't mind!')
Tightening the leash (increases frustration)
Not having a plan before greetings happen

commands.name: Walk Nice (Loose Leash)
commands.description: Your dog walks calmly beside you without pulling on the leash.

steps.instruction: Start indoors. Walk with treats in your hand at your side. Reward frequently for being at your side.
steps.tip: Practice without a leash first to focus on positioning

steps.instruction: Add the leash. If tension occurs, stop walking. Only move forward when leash is loose.
steps.tip: You are a tree - pulling gets nothing

steps.instruction: When leash tightens, say nothing - just stop. When they look back or create slack, mark and move forward.
steps.tip: Forward motion is the reward

steps.instruction: Vary your pace and direction. Reward check-ins (when they look at you voluntarily).
steps.tip: Be interesting! Unpredictability keeps them engaged

steps.instruction: Practice in gradually more distracting environments. Start in your yard, then quiet streets, then busier areas.
steps.tip: Increase difficulty slowly - walks should be successful

tips: Use a front-clip harness or head halter for management while training
Let them sniff as a reward for good walking
Differentiate 'Heel' (formal) from casual loose leash walking
commonMistakes: Moving forward while the dog is pulling (reinforces pulling)
Jerking or pulling back on the leash
Expecting too much too fast - this takes weeks/months

commands.name: Door Manners
commands.description: Your dog waits calmly at doors and doesn't rush through without permission.

steps.instruction: At any door (front door, backyard, car), ask for a sit before reaching for the handle.
steps.tip: Sit is the 'magic word' for doors

steps.instruction: Reach for the handle. If they stand up, reset and wait for sit again.
steps.tip: Don't say anything - just reset

steps.instruction: Open the door slightly. If they stay sitting, open more. If they move, close it.
steps.tip: The door closing is the consequence - stay calm

steps.instruction: When door is fully open and they're still sitting, release with 'Okay!' or 'Free!'
steps.tip: They need permission to go through

steps.instruction: Practice at every door, every time. Consistency is everything.
steps.tip: This is safety training - worth the effort

tips: This prevents door dashing - potentially life-saving
Practice at car doors too
All family members must require this
commonMistakes: Letting them rush through sometimes
Not having everyone in the household on board
Forgetting to use a release cue

commands.name: Shake/Paw
commands.description: Your dog places their paw in your hand on cue.

steps.instruction: Have your dog sit. Hold a treat in your closed fist at their chest level.
steps.tip: Position your hand low to encourage paw movement

steps.instruction: Wait. Most dogs will eventually paw at your hand. Click immediately when they touch your hand with their paw.
steps.tip: Be patient - wait them out

steps.instruction: Open your hand to deliver the treat. Reset and repeat.
steps.tip: The paw touch opens the treat hand

steps.instruction: Present your open palm. Say 'Shake' or 'Paw' when they touch it.
steps.tip: Add the cue once they understand the game

steps.instruction: Gently hold their paw briefly before treating. Build up to a proper handshake.
steps.tip: Keep it fun and low-pressure

tips: Great starter trick to build training confidence
Some dogs offer paws naturally - capture it!
Alternate hands to prevent single-side bias
commonMistakes: Grabbing their paw instead of waiting for them to offer
Not clicking at the exact moment of paw touch
Moving on before the basic lift is reliable

commands.name: High Five
commands.description: Your dog raises their paw high to slap your hand.

steps.instruction: Once 'Shake' is solid, hold your hand higher - at your dog's shoulder level or above.
steps.tip: This is just a higher shake

steps.instruction: When they reach up to touch your hand, click and treat.
steps.tip: Reward the upward motion

steps.instruction: Gradually raise your hand position until it's at a 'high five' angle.
steps.tip: Palm facing the dog

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'High Five' and use an animated voice.
steps.tip: Make it fun and exciting

steps.instruction: Practice standing up, kneeling, from different positions.
steps.tip: Dogs often don't generalize - practice in different contexts

tips: Perfect for photos and showing off
Can combine with 'Shake' for a routine
Some dogs prefer this to shake
commonMistakes: Raising hand too high too fast
Expecting it before shake is solid
Not rewarding effort toward the higher position

commands.name: Spin (Left)
commands.description: Your dog turns in a circle to their left.

steps.instruction: Hold a treat at your dog's nose. Slowly lure them in a circle to their left.
steps.tip: Keep the treat close to their nose throughout

steps.instruction: Complete the full circle and click/treat when they end up facing you.
steps.tip: Go slow enough that they follow without confusion

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Spin' (or 'Spin Left') just before starting the lure.
steps.tip: Be consistent with your cue choice

steps.instruction: Gradually reduce the lure. Make a smaller circle motion with your hand.
steps.tip: The hand signal becomes a small twirl of your finger

steps.instruction: Try chaining multiple spins: 2, then 3 before treating.
steps.tip: Fun for dancing routines!

tips: Practice on a non-slip surface
Some dogs get dizzy - don't overdo it
Teach both directions separately
commonMistakes: Luring too fast (dog can't follow)
Raising the lure (causes jumping)
Not completing the full circle before clicking

commands.name: Spin (Right)
commands.description: Your dog turns in a circle to their right.

steps.instruction: Hold a treat at your dog's nose. Slowly lure them in a circle to their right.
steps.tip: Mirror image of Spin Left

steps.instruction: Complete the full circle and click/treat when they end up facing you.
steps.tip: Go the same speed as Spin Left

steps.instruction: Add a different cue: 'Twist' or 'Spin Right' to distinguish from left.
steps.tip: Using a different word helps dogs distinguish

steps.instruction: Use the opposite hand to help distinguish. Left hand for left spin, right hand for right.
steps.tip: Hand signals become important

steps.instruction: Alternate between left and right spins for a fun sequence.
steps.tip: Dogs love the variety

tips: Wait until left spin is solid before teaching right
Some dogs have a preferred direction
Great for music routines
commonMistakes: Teaching both directions at the same time
Using the same cue word for both
Not giving clear hand signals

commands.name: Roll Over
commands.description: Your dog rolls 360 degrees from lying down, over their back, and back up.

steps.instruction: Start with your dog in a 'Down.' Have them on a comfortable, soft surface.
steps.tip: Hard floors make this uncomfortable

steps.instruction: Hold a treat at their nose, then lure toward their shoulder. They should shift their weight to their hip.
steps.tip: Move slowly - this is the setup position

steps.instruction: Continue the lure motion over their shoulder and along their spine. They should roll onto their back.
steps.tip: Go at their pace - clicking progress along the way

steps.instruction: Complete the lure so they roll all the way over and end up back in Down. Big reward!
steps.tip: Celebrate this win!

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Roll Over' and gradually reduce the lure to a hand signal.
steps.tip: A rolling hand motion works well

tips: Some dogs roll more easily in one direction
Reward partial attempts at first
Don't force the motion physically
commonMistakes: Practicing on hard floors (painful)
Moving the lure too fast
Expecting it in one session

commands.name: Play Dead
commands.description: Your dog lies on their side and holds completely still, playing dead.

steps.instruction: Start with your dog in a Down. Lure them onto their hip (same as Roll Over start).
steps.tip: The hip position is key

steps.instruction: Once they're on their hip, wait. Reward for stillness rather than continuing the roll.
steps.tip: We want them to stop here

steps.instruction: Add a dramatic cue like 'Bang!' with a finger gun gesture.
steps.tip: This is part of the fun!

steps.instruction: Build duration of the 'dead' position: 1 second, 3 seconds, 5 seconds.
steps.tip: Reward for staying still

steps.instruction: Release with 'Okay!' or 'You're alive!' Practice from a stand for dramatic effect.
steps.tip: The performance aspect is what makes it fun

tips: Keep your energy playful, not serious
Some dogs prefer full side-lie, others hip position
Great photo opportunity trick
commonMistakes: Rewarding before they're fully still
Not differentiating from Roll Over
Taking it too seriously (should be fun!)

commands.name: Speak
commands.description: Your dog barks on command.

steps.instruction: Find what makes your dog bark: doorbell, knocking, a toy held out of reach, excited play.
steps.tip: Every dog has a bark trigger

steps.instruction: When they bark, say 'Speak!' and immediately reward. Pair the word with the natural bark.
steps.tip: Capture the natural behavior

steps.instruction: Present the trigger, say 'Speak,' wait for bark, reward.
steps.tip: Start creating the command association

steps.instruction: Gradually fade the trigger. Say 'Speak' without the external trigger.
steps.tip: This may take time

steps.instruction: Reward only when they bark on cue, not random barking.
steps.tip: Be very clear about when barking is rewarded

tips: This helps teach 'Quiet' (gives you an on/off switch)
Only reward a single bark, not a barking frenzy
Practice rarely so it stays special
commonMistakes: Rewarding extended barking
Practicing so much they bark constantly
Using in situations where quiet is preferred

commands.name: Bow
commands.description: Your dog stretches into a 'play bow' position with front end down, rear end up.

steps.instruction: Start with your dog standing. Hold a treat at their nose.
steps.tip: They must be standing, not sitting

steps.instruction: Lure the treat down between their front legs toward their chest. Their front end should lower.
steps.tip: Don't go too far back or they'll lie down

steps.instruction: Click and treat when their elbows hit the ground but rear end stays up.
steps.tip: Timing is crucial - click before they lie all the way down

steps.instruction: You can gently support under their belly to prevent lying down if needed.
steps.tip: Light touch, not holding

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Bow' or 'Take a Bow.' Great for ending a training session!
steps.tip: Make it theatrical

tips: Capture natural play bows when they happen
Perfect for the end of a trick routine
Dogs often do this naturally when stretching
commonMistakes: Luring too far down (becomes a down)
Starting from a sit instead of stand
Not clicking quickly enough

commands.name: Wave
commands.description: Your dog raises a paw and moves it back and forth like waving hello or goodbye.

steps.instruction: Once Shake or High Five is solid, hold your hand out but don't let them touch it.
steps.tip: We want the reach without contact

steps.instruction: Click and treat when they lift their paw toward your hand but before they touch.
steps.tip: The movement is the goal, not the touch

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Wave' and use a waving hand gesture yourself.
steps.tip: Your wave becomes the visual cue

steps.instruction: To get the 'waving' motion, delay the click slightly - they'll often paw repeatedly at the air.
steps.tip: The frustration creates the wave motion

steps.instruction: Practice at a distance - great for greeting guests or for photos.
steps.tip: Build distance slowly

tips: Works best once High Five is solid
Natural for dogs who paw a lot
Great for greeting and goodbye
commonMistakes: Clicking when they touch your hand (that's shake)
Teaching before shake is reliable
Not being patient for the waving motion

commands.name: Touch (Target)
commands.description: Your dog touches their nose to your palm or a target stick.

steps.instruction: Hold your flat palm a few inches from your dog's nose. Most dogs will investigate.
steps.tip: Don't move toward them - let them come to you

steps.instruction: The moment their nose touches your palm, click and treat from your other hand.
steps.tip: Mark the exact moment of touch

steps.instruction: Move your palm to different positions - left, right, higher, lower. Reward each touch.
steps.tip: Make it a game

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Touch' before presenting your palm.
steps.tip: One clear word

steps.instruction: Transfer to a target stick or other objects (post-it note, lid, etc.).
steps.tip: The same skill transfers to any object

tips: Foundation skill for many tricks and behaviors
Use for heel position, recalls, getting on scales, etc.
Great for nervous dogs - builds confidence
commonMistakes: Pushing your palm into their face
Not having a treat ready in the other hand
Moving the target too fast once they understand

commands.name: Crawl
commands.description: Your dog moves forward while staying in a down position.

steps.instruction: Start with your dog in a Down. Kneel next to them with your arm over their back (to prevent standing).
steps.tip: Your arm is a gentle barrier, not pressing down

steps.instruction: Lure with a treat just in front of their nose, moving it slowly forward along the ground.
steps.tip: Keep the treat on the ground

steps.instruction: Click and treat any forward movement while staying low. Even an inch counts!
steps.tip: Reward small progress

steps.instruction: Gradually increase the distance before rewarding. First one inch, then three, then six.
steps.tip: Build up slowly

steps.instruction: Remove your arm barrier once they understand the motion. Add the cue 'Crawl.'
steps.tip: Phase out the physical prompt

tips: Use a soft surface - carpet or grass
Can practice under a low obstacle to encourage staying low
Great core workout for your dog
commonMistakes: Luring too fast (they stand up)
Pressing down on them (creates resistance)
Expecting too much distance too soon

commands.name: Back Up
commands.description: Your dog walks backward away from you on cue.

steps.instruction: In a narrow hallway or between furniture, walk toward your standing dog.
steps.tip: The narrow space limits their options

steps.instruction: As they back up to make room for you, click and toss a treat behind them.
steps.tip: Reward the movement with a thrown treat

steps.instruction: Add the cue 'Back' or 'Back Up' just before walking toward them.
steps.tip: Pair the word with the action

steps.instruction: Practice in more open areas. Take a step toward them only if needed.
steps.tip: Fade your movement forward

steps.instruction: Build distance: one step back, then two, then five.
steps.tip: Always throw the treat behind them

tips: Useful for creating space in doorways or tight spaces
Some dogs find this challenging - be patient
Rear-end awareness exercises help
commonMistakes: Not using spatial pressure (narrow space) initially
Rewarding at your feet (brings them forward again)
Moving too quickly toward them
